title: Straight-Line Sprint Tests
equipment: Flat running surface with start/finish lines at set distances (e.g., 10 m, 20 m, 40 m or 40 yd/37 m) with sufficient run-out for deceleration
procedure: Warm up and dynamic stretching for several minutes
At least two practice runs at submaximal speed
Start position uses a three- or four-point stance
On an auditory signal, sprint the specified distance at maximal speed
Record best split time from two trials (nearest 0.1 s)
Allow at least ~2 minutes recovery (active or rest) between trials
notes: Normative data referenced in a chapter table (10 m, 20 m, 40 m, and 40-yard/37 m).

title: Pro Agility Test (20-yard shuttle)
equipment: Field marked with three parallel lines 5 yards (4.6 m) apart
procedure: Athlete straddles center line in a three-point stance
On signal: sprint 5 yd to one side line, touch with hand (keep consistent hand/contact rules across trials)
Change direction and sprint 10 yd to far line, touch
Change direction and sprint 5 yd back through center line
Record best of two trials (nearest 0.01 s)
notes: Normative data referenced in a chapter table near the end.

title: 505 Agility Test
procedure: Set up cones and timing per layout
Warm up; allow practice at submax effort
Start at start line
On signal: sprint 10 m to timing gate, then continue ~5 m to turning line
At turning line: one foot must be on/over the line, turn and accelerate back
Time recorded when passing back through timing system
Best of two trials recorded (nearest 0.1 s)
Trials can be done turning off preferred leg; can also test both legs
notes: Descriptive data referenced in a chapter table.

title: Hexagon Test
procedure: Tape a hexagon on the floor (commonly 24-inch / 61 cm sides, 120° angles per figure)
Warm up and practice at submax effort
Start standing in the center
On signal: double-leg hop out and back to center, moving around the hexagon in a clockwise sequence until completing the prescribed number of revolutions/jumps
If athlete lands on a side, loses balance, adds steps, or changes facing direction: stop and restart after recovery
Record best time of three trials (nearest 0.1 s)
notes: Descriptive data referenced in a chapter table.

title: T-Test
procedure: Arrange cones in T layout (per figure)
Warm up and stretch; allow practice run
Start at point A
On signal: sprint forward to B and touch cone base with right hand
Shuffle left to C and touch with left hand (no crossing feet, stay facing forward)
Shuffle right across to D and touch with right hand
Shuffle left back to B and touch with left hand, then run backward past A to finish (timer stops)
Record best of two trials (nearest 0.1 s)
Disqualify if athlete fails to touch base, crosses feet during shuffle, or fails to face forward for the test
notes: Descriptive data referenced in a chapter table.

title: Maximal Aerobic Speed (MAS) Test
equipment: Audio software for MAS test and a way to broadcast audio (e.g., speakers)
procedure: Place marker cones at fixed intervals around track (e.g., 25 m)
Set initial speed based on fitness (commonly 8–12 km/h; often start at ~10 km/h)
Increase speed by 1 km/h every 2 minutes until athlete cannot maintain pace
Speed maintained for at least ~2 minutes is treated as MAS (associated with VO2max)
Terminate when athlete fails to reach the next cone on two consecutive occasions
If athlete completes half-stage: final speed can be adjusted by +0.5 km/h
Estimate VO2max as 3.5 × MAS (km/h)
notes: Norms referenced in a chapter table.

title: Yo-Yo Intermittent Recovery Test (IRT1/IRT2)
equipment: Yo-Yo IRT audio and playback method (e.g., speakers)
procedure: Set up a 20 m shuttle with markers (and a recovery/jog zone as specified by the protocol)
Warm up; allow practice at submax effort
Begin at start line
On audio signal: run to turning line and back in time with beeps; jog recovery during designated recovery intervals
Athlete must place one foot on/over lines at each beep
Continue while maintaining required pace indicated by audio
Terminate after failing to reach the line on time for two trials (with a warning after first miss)
Record last level and number of shuttles completed; use final score to compute total distance covered (per protocol)
notes: Descriptive data referenced in a chapter table.

title: 1.5-Mile Run and 12-Minute Run
equipment: Measured running course or track (1.5-mile / 2.4 km; alternate course acceptable)
For 12-min run: track or loop with distance markers
personnel: For 1.5-mile: one tester calling out each athlete’s time + one recorder
For 12-min: one tester calling out positions + one recorder
procedure: 1.5-mile: warm up; start on signal; complete as fast as possible; record finishing time (mm:ss)
12-min: warm up; start on signal; cover as much distance as possible in 12 minutes; record total distance
notes: Normative data referenced in chapter tables; tables may also estimate VO2max or related metrics.

title: YMCA Bench Press Test
equipment: Barbell, plates, locks sufficient to load 80 lb (36 kg) for males or 35 lb (16 kg) for females (including locks)
Flat bench press station with rack (preferably upright rack)
procedure: Teach proper bench press technique
Spotter/recorder stands at head of bench to assist on failed reps and record reps
Set resistance: 80 lb males / 35 lb females
Set metronome cadence at 60 bpm (≈30 reps/min; one beat up, one beat down)
Grip shoulder-width; lift off rack; extend elbows
Perform repetitions in time with metronome until cadence cannot be maintained
Movement should be smooth/controlled; full ROM consistent with protocol
notes: Normative data referenced in chapter table.

title: Push-Up Test (Army / ACSM variants)
equipment: Foam roller (4-inch diameter) used as a depth marker for some female protocols
procedure: Protocol differs by standard (Army vs ACSM) and by sex (ACSM female uses knees/ankles crossed)
For Army: standard push-up position; low position typically defined by upper arms parallel to floor
For ACSM males: low position when chest contacts judge’s fist held vertically; females may use foam roller torso contact as depth marker
Reps not meeting depth are not counted
Army: as many reps as possible in timed ~2-minute period; pausing allowed only in up position
ACSM: as many reps as possible continuously until fatigue
notes: Normative data referenced in chapter tables; Army scoring points referenced in a separate table.

title: Partial Curl-Up Test
procedure: Supine on mat with knees bent (~90°); arms at sides with fingers touching a tape marker
Set a second tape marker perpendicular/parallel based on age-related distance guideline
Set metronome to 40 bpm; perform controlled curl-ups at set cadence (commonly 20 curl-ups/min)
Upper back touches floor before each rep; avoid neck flexion
Continue without pausing up to a maximum cap (e.g., 75) depending on protocol
notes: Normative data referenced in chapter table.

title: 300-Yard (274 m) Shuttle
equipment: Two parallel lines 25 yards (22.86 m) apart on a flat surface
procedure: Pair athletes of similar ability
Start behind one line facing the opposite line
On signal: sprint to opposite line (touch with foot contact), turn and sprint back; complete six round trips (6 × 50 yd = 300 yd)
Record trial time to nearest 0.1 s
Rest interval ~5 minutes between trials; keep athletes alert for second trial start
Average of two trials recorded to nearest 0.1 s
notes: Descriptive data referenced in a chapter table.

title: Margaría–Kalamen Stair Sprint Test
equipment: Staircase with ~9+ steps (~7 in / 18 cm each) and straight approach area (~20 ft / 6 m)
Electronic timing with start/stop switch mechanisms
procedure: Measure step height and compute vertical rise from third to ninth step (6 × step height)
Place start switch on third step and stop switch on ninth step
Weigh athlete; warm up; practice running stairs three steps at a time
Sprint from a standing start ~20 ft from stairs; run up three steps at a time
Record time from third to ninth step contact (nearest 0.01 s)
Compute power using body weight (in newtons) × vertical rise (m) ÷ time (s)
Repeat 2–3 trials with ~2–3 minutes recovery
notes: Normative data referenced in chapter table.

title: Reactive Strength Index (RSI) / Drop Jump Test
equipment: Boxes of varying heights (example: 20 cm, 30 cm, 40 cm)
Device to measure contact time and jump height (e.g., jump/contact mat system)
procedure: Stand on box with contact mat placed in front
Hands on hips; step forward off box (do not jump up or down)
On ground contact: jump as high as possible while minimizing contact time
Keep strategy consistent across trials
Record jump height and contact time; take best of three trials
Compute RSI as jump height ÷ contact time
Repeat using multiple box heights to profile stretch tolerance

title: Static Vertical Jump (Squat Jump) using Contact Mat
equipment: Contact mat system or force plate system
procedure: Begin standing on mat (countermovement removed)
Descend to squat position (~110° knee angle) and hold 2–3 seconds
Jump vertically
Record jump height; best of three trials
Optional: compute eccentric utilization ratio vs countermovement jump
notes: Descriptive data referenced in a chapter table.

title: Vertical Jump (Wall/Chalk or Vertec device)
equipment: Smooth wall taller than jump reach
Alternative: commercial vertical jump device (e.g., Vertec)
procedure: Wall/chalk: mark standing reach height with dominant hand
Perform countermovement jump and mark highest touch; score is difference between marks
Record best of three trials (typical precision: ~0.5 in / 1 cm)
Vertec: set vane stack to standing reach; adjust height; jump and tap highest possible vane; score is difference between reach height and highest vane
notes: Descriptive data referenced in chapter table.

title: 1RM Power Clean
equipment: Olympic-style barbell with revolving sleeves + plates + safety locks
Lifting platform or designated safe lifting area
procedure: Teach proper power clean technique
Perform warm-up sets and incremental loading similar to 1RM testing procedures (e.g., bench)
Refer to standard 1RM testing protocol for attempt structure
notes: Acknowledges that technical demand can cause athletes with similar power capacity to test differently; interpret accordingly.
Normative/descriptive data referenced in chapter tables.

title: Standing Long Jump
equipment: Alternative: commercial jump mat with marked increments
procedure: Mark a starting line (tape)
Athlete stands with toes behind line
Countermovement and jump forward as far as possible
Must land on both feet; otherwise repeat trial
Measure from start line to back edge of rearmost heel
Record best of three trials (nearest 0.5 in / 1 cm)
notes: Normative/descriptive data referenced in chapter tables.

title: 1RM Back Squat
equipment: Sturdy squat rack with adjustable spotting bars (or spotters)
procedure: Teach proper back squat technique
Warm-up sets and loading increments similar to 1RM bench, but generally heavier attempts/increments
Use standard 1RM testing protocol structure
notes: Normative/descriptive data referenced in chapter tables.

title: 1RM Bench Press
equipment: Sturdy bench press bench with integral bar rack (preferably adjustable height)
procedure: Teach proper flat bench technique
Spotter stays at head of bench to assist if needed
Use specific warm-up and progressive load attempts
Typically complete a couple heavier warm-up sets of a few reps before first true 1RM attempt
Aim to find 1RM within ~3–5 heavy attempts after warm-up to limit fatigue
notes: Detailed step-by-step 1RM protocol referenced elsewhere in the book (figure).
Normative/descriptive data referenced in chapter tables.

title: 1RM Bench Pull
procedure: Teach proper bench pull setup and technique (per figure)
Closed pronated grip wider than shoulder width
Bench height allows comfortable hang position without plates touching ground
Start from hang position; maintain consistent grip and setup
Follow standard 1RM protocol attempt structure
notes: Normative/descriptive data referenced in chapter table.
